content.text: Xcode version requirements and updated deployment targets

inlineContent.text: require Xcode 14.1 or later. The minimum deployment targets have also been updated.
The table below lists the libraries provided in
Location features have been extracted into a separate library,
. This library is optional and can be added to your project if you wish to use location features.
library to streamline the rich push integration.
In order to make the migration easier, we provide compatibility libraries that can be used to replace the
classes and methods that were available in the
Includes deprecation warnings to update your code to use the new
classes and methods that were available in the

This section presents different migration scenarios based on your project’s needs. At the end of any standalone scenario, your application will be in compile order and can be tested and submitted to the App Store.
The minimal migration scenario allows you to quickly get your application in compile order. It does not require any changes to your code apart from updating import statements.
methods and symbols are functional. However, they are marked as deprecated and you will need to update your code to use the new
classes and methods in a future major release.

content.text: Step 1: Replace the Appboy SDK with the Braze SDK compatibility libraries

inlineContent.text: In Xcode, select your project at the top of the Project Navigator (left side bar).
Select your project again above the
In Xcode, select your project at the top of the Project Navigator (left side bar).
Select your project again above the
In Xcode, select your project at the top of the Project Navigator (left side bar).
Select your project again above the
To start using the compatibility APIs, you must update your import statements to use the
Apps fully written in Objective-C may not need to update import statements. The Appboy-iOS-SDK headers are still available in the compatibility libraries when integrating via SwiftPM or CocoaPods.
CocoaPods users may encounter the error
This error may occur as soon as you import
To resolve this error, you must import
Your application should now be in compile order and can be tested and submitted to the App Store.
Migrating to the Braze iOS SDK requires re-identifying users. To do so, you must call the

code: // Re-identify a logged in user with the Braze SDK

inlineContent.text: Migrate each features one by one to the new APIs.
To perform the full migration, you:
(if applicable) in addition of the compatibility libraries:
Swift Package Manager: Link the libraries in section
of your application target configuration page.
(optional) pods to your Podfile and run
Must add import statements for these libraries where applicable.

code: import BrazeKit // Required to use the new APIs

inlineContent.text: This enables all the deprecation warnings to help guide your migration process.
This enables the use of new features available only via the
Updating the SDK initialization code to use the
disables the compatibility APIs. This step must be performed last, once you have verified that you do not rely on any compatibility API.
Compiling your application at this point should result in a lot of deprecation warnings:
Checking these warnings messages is the easiest way to migrate your code.
Some of these warnings may be able to automatically update the code via the
Braze does not support pre-iOS 10 deprecated push notification handling methods (e.g.
). The use of these deprecated APIs can lead to unexpected behaviors and make your push notification integration harder to diagnostic.
Braze now automatically reads the user permission and notification settings once the user has interacted with the permission prompt.
Braze push notification handling methods now return a boolean value indicating whether the notification originates from Braze and was processed by the SDK.
This enables your application to integrate the Braze push notification feature alongside other push notification providers (e.g. in-house push notification system).
Previously, support for rich push notifications was provided via a
fully compatible with the Braze SDK
and you will still be able to receive and process rich push notifications if you leave that code unchanged.
Nonetheless, we recommend migrating to using our
library. Migrating to this new integration method ensures that your
is automatically updated when updating the Braze SDK.
The easiest way to migrate this feature is by:
Following the steps in our tutorial
Support for Push Stories notifications was provided via a
fully compatible with the Braze SDK
and you will still be able to receive and process Push Stories notifications if you leave that code unchanged.
Nonetheless, we recommend migrating to using our
library. Migrating to this new integration method ensures that your integration is automatically updated when updating the Braze SDK.
The easiest way to migrate this feature is by:
Following the steps in our tutorial
We have updated our UI components to provide a better user experience and to be more easily customizable.
does not support GIFs out of the box. See
Registering the In-App Message UI is now a manual step. To use the Braze In-App Message UI, follow our tutorial

If you were previously customizing the appearance or behavior of the Appboy In-App Message UI (e.g. via subclassing), these customizations will be lost. The Braze In-App Message UI provides more customization APIs, see
BrazeUI provides updated Content Cards UI components:
To use the Braze Content Cards UI, follow our tutorial

If you were previously customizing the appearance or behavior of the Appboy Content Cards UI (e.g. via subclassing), these customizations will be lost. The Braze Content Cards UI provides more customization APIs, see
Braze does not provide a NewsFeed UI. The Appboy NewsFeed UI is still available when using both
If your application relies on the Appboy NewsFeed UI, you will not be able to complete the migration and perform the
section of this guide. Your application and your Braze integration will remain fully functional, even when using the deprecated initialization method.
The table below matches Appboy public protocols with their equivalent in the Braze SDK.
delegate method is now accessible via
The boolean value returned by this method is now used to determine whether the URL should be opened by Braze (
This is the opposite of the previous behavior, where the return value of
was used to determine whether the URL should be opened by Appboy (
Updating the SDK initialization and configuration is the last step to finish the migration process. Performing this step will prevent you from using any compatibility APIs.
Acknowledge the warning below before continuing
Before updating the SDK initialization and configuration, you:
Must migrate all available features and deprecated methods
All compatibility APIs including all deprecated symbols, all
symbols will not work after updating the SDK initialization.
At this point, you may still use
After updating the SDK initialization and configuration, the SDK:
Will not emit the Content Cards and NewsFeed updates via the Notification Center.
Will not support GIFs out of the box.
The Braze SDK does not offer singleton APIs. You are now responsible for creating the
instance and keeping a strong reference to it for the duration of your use of the Braze SDK:

code: // Keep a strong reference to it

initializer. The Braze SDK remains active as long as the instance is alive.
We recommend storing the instance somewhere easily accessible, for instance, as a static property of your
